sub_topic: Riemann mapping theorem and its applications
message_1: Suppose the region $\mathbb{D}=\{z\in\mathbb{C}:|z|<1 \}$ is mapped conformally onto the region $\mathbb{H}=\{z\in\mathbb{C}:\mathrm{Im}(z)>0 \}$ by the Riemann mapping theorem. Find the image of the point $0.8i$ under this map.
message_2:
To find the image of the point $0.8i$ under the conformal map, we can use the well-known conformal map from the unit disk $\mathbb{D}$ to the upper half-plane $\mathbb{H}$, which is given by the MÃ¶bius transformation:

$$f(z) = \frac{z - i}{z + i}$$

Applying this transformation to the point $0.8i$, we get:

$$f(0.8i) = \frac{0.8i - i}{0.8i + i} = \frac{-0.2i}{1.8i}$$

Now, we can divide the numerator and denominator by $-0.2i$:

$$f(0.8i) = \frac{-0.2i}{1.8i} \cdot \frac{-1}{0.2} = \frac{1}{-9}$$

So, the image of the point $0.8i$ under the conformal map is $\frac{1}{-9}$.
